SharkFlow - provides answers to all common user questions

string-array.name: faq_array_question
string-array.item: How is user data encryption ensured?
Who has access to the information in the database?
How often are backups performed and where are they stored?
How is monitoring and anomaly detection performed?
What measures are taken to protect against DDoS attacks?
Where are the servers located and do they meet security standards?
How are incidents and violation notifications handled?
What privacy guarantees are provided to the user?
How is unauthorized access prevented?
How is system scaling and updating planned?

string-array.name: faq_array_answer
string-array.item: All data is transmitted via HTTPS with TLS encryption, and passwords are stored in the database only as salted bcrypt hashes.
Access is strictly limited: only service components and administrators with multi-factor authentication can work with the data.
Backups are performed every 6 hours and stored in geo-distributed repositories with object-level encryption.
The logging system is integrated with a SIEM platform for 24/7 monitoring and automatic alerts on suspicious activity.
A distributed CDN network with built-in WAF and automatic scaling is used to filter and mitigate targeted loads.
Servers are located in certified Tier III data centers compliant with ISO 27001 and SOC 2 standards.
In the event of an incident, the ICS procedure is activated: notifying the response team, analysis, mitigation, and reporting within 24 hours.
We commit not to share data with third parties and to use it solely for service delivery in accordance with our GDPR policy.
Strict role policies, session control, IP blocking, and login attempt limits are enforced.
Updates are deployed via a CI/CD pipeline with Canary releases and automated load testing to ensure service continuity.

string-array.item: User passwords are never stored in plain text - bcrypt with salt is used.

Only authorized users and services with limited rights have access to the data.
We do not share, sell, or use personal data for third-party purposes.
The database is regularly backed up to protect against failures and data loss.
